results.title: Clever Hiko Ichi
results.brief_description: Provides a backdrop for language arts activities such as storytelling, creative dramatics, and reading, by presenting an animated story about a little boy in medieval Japan who solves three difficult problems with a bit of applied science and personal fortitude.

results.title: Clerical work
results.creator_credit: Mutual Film Corporation and Career Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Is this your career series”.
This is a field of work with many opportunities: secretaries, optometrists, general clerks, receptionists, bank teller, enquiry clerk, accountant and section head. Shows that with machines performing the monotonous jobs, todays office work is concerned more with planning and people. Part of the “Is this your career?”series.

results.title: Clerambard
results.brief_description:
Clerambard lives on the edge of poverty in an old castle. He ekes a living out of killing cats and dogs and exploiting his family. His life is turned updside down after reading ‘The life of St Fancis of Assissi’. The Saint even appears to help Clerambard go out into the world to preach the gospel and reveal his newfound love of animals.

Credits: Producers, Yves Robert, Alain Poire ; director, Yves Robert ; writers, Jean-Loup Dabadie, Yves Robert ; photography, Rene Mathelin ; music, Vladimir Cosma.
Cast: Philippe Noiret, Dany Carrel, Lise Delamare, Gerard Lartigau, Claude Pieplu, Roger Carel, Martine Sarcey.

results.title: Cleopatra and Antony
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Famous women of the past”.
Cleopatra, Queen of Egypt, friend and lover of Caesar, Roman Emperor. He is murdered, but she has a son, Caesarion. She is determined to have Caesar’s nephew, Octavian, (Emperor of Rome), removed and Caesarean in his place. To help the process she tries to befriend Mark Antony, the great Roman warrior. Antony succumbs to Cleopatra, and their relationship becomes unbreakable. Antony declares war on Rome to bring Caesarion to the throne - but after ten years of war, does not succeed, and their tragic deaths soon follow.

results.title: Cleopatra [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Walter Wanger, Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and Joseph L Mankiewicz
results.brief_description: Elizabeth Taylor, Richard Burton and Rex Harrison star in this tale of power and betrayal - the legendary story of the Queen of the Nile and her conquest of Julius Caesar and Marc Antony. An unforgettable portrayal of the beguiling beauty who seduced two of Rome’s greatest soldiers and changed the course of history. Also stars: Pamela Brown, George Cole, Hume Cronyn, Cesare Danova, Kenneth Haigh, Andrew Keir, Martin Landau, Roddy McDowall, Robert Stephens and Francesca Annis. Music by Alex North. Screenplay by Joseph L. Mankiewicz, Ranald MacDougall and Sidney Buchman. Cinematography by Leon Shamroy. (Academy Awards: Cinematography, Art direction, Costumes, Sets and Special effects)

results.title: Cleopatra
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Famous women of the past”.
A narrated account of Cleopatra’s war against her younger brother, Ptolemy, and her later influence on Julius Caesar. The film uses paints of historical events and classical music adds dramatic effect.

results.title: Cleo from 5 to 7 = Cleo de 5 a 7
results.creator_credit: Georges de Beauregard, Rome Paris Films and Agnes Varda
results.brief_description: Varda was the premiere female director of her generation and part of the French New Wave. Her first fully realised feature, ‘Cleo de 5 a 7’ documents, in real time, two or so hours in the life of a young woman awaiting the results of medical tests; she fears the worst. Through an arresting use of Paris as both a visual centerpiece and a reflection of a woman’s inner journey, Varda paints an enduring portrait of Cleo’s evolution from a shallow child-woman to a person who can feel and express shock, anguish, and finally empathy. A spirited mix of verite and melodrama, the film features a score by Michel Legrand (Umbrellas of Cherbourg) and cameos by Legrand, Godard and Anna Karina. One of the few films in which the duration of the fiction approximates actual clock time. Cast includes Corinne Marchand, Antoine Bourseiller, Dominique Davray and Dorothee Blank. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Clementine Tango
results.brief_description:
Charles, a law student, shares a sumptuous Paris apartment with his sister. One day, he finds a very strange love letter in the pocket of his father’s tuxedo. While trying to understand his father’s love entanglements, he is led to a Pigalle nightclub where act after act is performed with the intent of splintering bourgeois sexual mores into humorous pieces. The ‘cinema du look’ is not quite confined to the films of Beineix, Besson and Carax, the tree neo-baroque ‘wonder boys’. Caroline Roboh’s camp cabaret ‘Clementine Tango’ (1982) belongs to the genre too, as does Virginie Thevenet ‘La nuit porte-jaretelles’ (1985), which led ‘Les Cahiers du Cinema’ to coin the phrase ‘style Forum des Halles’, and prompted an attack from ‘Positif’ on the quality of the narrative, acting, and portrayal of sexuality.” Guy Austin. ‘Contemporary French cinema’. Manchester University Press, 1996.

Credits: Producer, Vladimir Forgency ; director, Caroline Roboh ; writer, Caroline Roboh ; photography, Mario Barroso.
Cast: Claire Pascal, Francois Helvey, Caroline Roboh, Arturo Brachetti, Josephine Larsen.

results.title: Clement Meadmore
results.brief_description: A modern sculptor in steel. This film is a plea for a sensible approach to modern art. It opens with Clement Meadmore welding a sculpture in his backyard in Sydney, followed by a survey of his works. Meadmore, who is also a leading designer in the field of fabrics and textiles, works with austere and means creating sculptures of purity of form and clarity of expression. Filmed, written and edited by Bruce Beresford. Narrated by John Bell.

results.creator_credit: Jan Sharp, Curtis Levy and Film Australia
